reviewText:
This game actually ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• me off.
No matter what way you try to put it, Emily is actually emotionally abusive. Like seriously, she guilt trips and gaslights you, both of which are forms of emotional abuse. Yet the game tries to guide you towards appeasing her and acts like she's the one in the right. I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing hate that. It makes me feel like a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for doing absolutely nothing wrong.
Go to the party at the beginning of the game? You get cucked by Brad.
Don't go, and tell her to not talk to Brad? You get cucked by Travis anyway. Both of whom are jerks to her.
You try to get into a relationship and try to be as nice as you can? She acts like you're a complete creeper and wanted nothing more than to have sex with her, she's weirded out by you.
Act like just a friend? She gets all weird on you asking why you didn't come on to her.
Call all of her friends out? She just laughs in your face.
Be a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• back to her? She stops talking to you. And that's what you want. You don't want her to talk to you, because she's a genuinely terrible human being.
On top of that, the main character is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing cucklord and I hate him, he missed his chance of getting with the decent girl because of his dumb obsession with Emily.
I'm not really for a game that's supposed to have moral choices but you can do nothing but wrong because the character who the choices are aimed towards is an insufferable, volatile ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

If your choices meant something, and Emily wasn't a completely horrible person, it'd be a neat concept. I like the whole idea of a visual novel-esque game set on an early IM chat interface. It's a neat idea. But being honest? dont take it personally babe it just aint your story" did a similar thing and did it better because your choices actually MEANT something. And if you complain about Emily being a more realistic character than anyone in that games
recommended: but is she a likeable character? Is she someone you'd spend several years of your life talking to? I know I wouldnt."

reviewText:
Before I talk about the ending I just want to say:

The chatlogs that happen is pretty realistic, feels nostalgia in a way as when leaving school, I had friends that I grew apart from because we never saw each other anymore and thats what this game feels like. It makes for an interesting playthrough (only 1 though) if you used AOL or MSN when you were younger.

PLAYTHROUGH 1:

I was pretty amazed not going to lie, the game felt almost real to me because I felt like I was having conversations like this when I was younger. Obviously when you're younger you say things without thinking of the meaning, so I played the game in the mind set of going through college and became more harsher as it went on. This pays off because I thought the ending was pretty realistic to my choices. So I tried again this time doing everything I thought Emily wanted to hear:

PLAYTHROUGH 2:

This is where I started to see a problem, my choices didn't make a difference to the outcome of the ending. Emily still got with Brad, my character is still the beta idiot he was in the other playthrough. I was hoping the game would be different in some way so I played it a final time:

PLAYTHROUGH 3:

I was a complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to Emily during this playthrough and first major choice is I didn't go to the party in the first year. This changed the story a tiny bit as Emily now dates Travis which is whatever. So I thought this playthrough I would get with Emma. It's going well I get to the final chapter and to my disappointment the ending still didn't change. Even to the point where I thought he would get with Emma, he didn't in the 3 YEARS he could have got with her. He did nothing which generally got me mad because this is meant to be an interactive story" where none of your choices matter
date:
kinda like the ending of  The Walking Dead	.

Ending

I don't know why the game is like this
recommended: there are so many points where it says "Emily will remember this" etc... and the pay off leads to no where. 3 completely different playthroughs lead to the same ending which is disappointing as this could have been an interesting game if any choices mattered.\n\nDo I recommend this game: Yes (it's free) but only for 1 playthrough
hoursPlayed:
don't waste your time playing it again.

Final thoughts:

The first playthrough was seriously amazing

reviewText:
This game hit a part of me that was encased deep in my being for months... I thought I had it under control, but this game opened that wound...

My Emily was a friend of mine in Skype... A really good friend.

That friend allowed me to talk about anything I wanted.

My insecurities, my problems, my successes, my failures, my joys, my upsets...

At the start of our relationship, she talked to me a lot, she'd talk to me about her plans and about her future, as well as her problems, which I gladly listened to and was the shoulder for her to cry...

She told me that she loved me for being there for her, because I really cared about her, I was the voice of reason for her, and sometimes she hated me for being like this, even if it meant the best for her... It was still my opinion, so I always told her it was her choice, anyways...

Later, she didn't have much time to talk to me, since she was having a lot of homework to do, or she needed to take care of her stepsister (which is handicapped, like she told me...).

She has lied to me before, with some petty stuff, but I always was there to forgive her, I don't have the heart to be mean to anybody, not even to her, even if she did this to me...

See you

reviewText:
This game is an experience. Not specifically a good one. Not specifically a bad one.
Many people may relate to this and feel emotionally attached. Many people won't.
The problem with this game is that it doesn't show you backstory of the player and the backstory of Emily. They're friends from what we gather and that's just it.
Emily then goes on to get a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• boyfriend, dump him, say we should make out, accuse you of wanting to smash, date ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• boyfriend again and ditch you.
The real emotion in this game comes with deeper thought.
A lot of the other reviews of this game and from my friend's experiences allow me to see that they feel sad as Emily is gone. She's gone forever and you have no way of talking to her again. Even after you cared for her all of these years. That's the problem. WE shouldn't feel sad. WE shouldn't want Emily to come back. She ditched us after all we've done and she should feel bad for doing so.
Yeah, she's gone and we can't speak to her.
Yeah, all those years have gone by.
HOWEVER, when she grows older, she will feel remember us and remember how her boyfriend hurt her and she we be sad.
Only then can we speak to her again; and by this time, things would have changed.

TLDR/CONCLUSION;

This game is interesting. It may come as a sudden shock for people but over time, things will get better. There is a glitter of hope in the end of this game, just as there is one in your life. Yes, I mean you - the reader. If you feel as if you can relate to this game in any way, things will get better. Just give it some time, just as this game would and it'll all end peachy.

reviewText: Harder than Dark Souls

reviewText:
All we wanted was to love her. We tried everything. We built up her confidence. We picked her up when she fell down. We lifted her spirits. We were, at least I thought we were, soulmates....

....

I have never been more wrong.

Emily, is without a doubt, the most pathetic and cruel human on the planet. No matter what we did, and no matter what we said, somehow, in Emily's mind, we took advantage of her, even though she is quoted as saying she doesn't regret ANYTHING, nor would take ANYTHING back, we still become the bad guy,..

HOW IS THAT FAIR?!?!?!?!

We tried to rescue her, from an emotionally and possibly physically abusive relationship, with epic toolbag BRAD. Then when she finally comes to her senses and leaves him, she visits us. And that is where it all goes wrong.... NO MATTER WHAT WE DO!

Then, in her delusional mind, she is rescued by EPIC TOOLBAG....BRAD. She treats like a villain, and proclaims BRAD to be the HERO....pshhh. What a load of crap!!!!

We are given NO free will, to truly speak our mind, to let her know how we truly feel about her (aka: WE LOVE HER), and absolutely NO option to win her back. Why give us options to say something, only to take them away, right before our eyes! That is cruelty. We worked up the courage to say it, before a robot from the Matrix came and erased our answers and replaced them with awkward small-talk, made by strangers. This is not even an accurate represenation of real life. You have heartache, but you never give up. You get turned down, but you keep trying, and fighting, and no robot EVER really comes to erase, and then replace your answers.

All in all, it was fun and interesting, and did bring back memories, and left me nostalgic for times past... BUT it left me wanting more. Much, much more. More freedom is needed to make this game more realistic, so that we are at least left with the impression that we can win Emily back. Or at least that we are given the option ourselves to turn down Emily, because quite frankly, she is the worst by the end of the game!

Bye.

Kate is away

reviewText:
Windows live messenger simulator 2015.

Better chat choices than fallout 10/10
voteText: 100 of 107 people (93%) found this review helpful 62 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Emily is Away is a visual novel game developed by a single developer, Kyle Seeley. The game was released for free in November 2015 and uses the popular visual novel game engine, Ren‚ÄôPy.

The game takes place in a classic MSN chat window, with your friend, Emily. Gameplay is very simple. You are offered a selection of responses as to what you type to Emily and she will respond accordingly. This is done in such a way that you actually have type out on your keyboard (you can also type out complete garbage and the game will still type out your response.) I wish I could type as fast as you do in this game‚Ä¶especially back in those days.

There isn‚Äôt much to say about the graphics, you are simply just sat in front of a Windows XP computer and your UI is the computer screen. It is clean and easy to navigate outside of the chat window.  You can check out other character‚Äôs MSN profiles, and see their good ol song lyrics that they have on there‚Ä¶but sadly you cannot communicate with them. I would of personally liked to have seen that as a feature, especially with the other characters which are key to the plot.

Emily is Away has a story which is somewhat interesting, if anyone has ever had some sort of ‚Äúone that got away‚Äù relationship with someone, this may strike a familiar tale with you. Personally I found it to be somewhat cringy in the way it plays out and the character Emily, comes across as someone who I wouldn‚Äôt want to associate with, but I given that  it gave me such strong feelings towards her, it means it is a well fleshed out character though. The story can be a little frustrating at times, since you only have three dialogue options at each interval, your feelings can not always be portrayed in the manner in which you want them to, which funnels your responses into three categories, one being pleasant, secondly being an on the fence response, or finally a blunt/unkind response, mainly you have one of these generic choices to make. The story does have a few elements that can change each time you play it, I played it through about six times and always saw something a bit different every time.  Without wanting to spoil too much, there is only one effective ending to the game, the way you get there can differ, but the outcome is always the same.

The audio in Emily is Away has very satisfying sound effects, the key strokes from typing come from that glorious sound of a mechanical keyboard, to Windows XP bootup/shutdown theme. There is no sound track, but you could always load up some Coldplay and get in the zone of your inner teenager from 2000 if you wanted‚Ä¶.

A single play through the story will take you roughly 15-20minutes, the game is split into six chapters spread out over six years. This is a short game, but given that it has a couple of different storylines you can explore via different options and choices, you can easily get about ninty minutes play out this if you wanted.

Technically Emily is Away is problem free. Obviously you are going to be wanting to play on a keyboard given that it is set in a chat client, and the game can run on a potato if you wanted it to.

To sum up, now the game is Free to play, I can recommend people try it out, it‚Äôs a short enough game that you aren‚Äôt really going to miss those twenty minutes if you don‚Äôt enjoy it.  Visual novel fans will definitely enjoy it, and like I said above, a certain group of people will certainly want to check it out if they have ever found themselves on the wrong side of the friendzone.

https://youtu.be/K60WoB_Q19U

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
The ultimate example of choices not mattering. Telltale looks good by comparison. Absolutely everything will go the exact same way no matter what you do. Allow Emily to visit you? You're a manipulative perv. Don't allow her to visit you? You're an insensitive jerk who lied about being there for her. Show an interest in another girl? You won't get her either.

This really feels like a game that wants to punish whoever plays it. You are constantly stonewalled and treated like a sucker, no matter what you do, by a hypocritical, guilt-tripping ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that you for some reason are still talking to after 5 years. By the end, the game even has the gall to erase what you type and replace it with what it wants you to say. And just in case you really wanted to test whether you can change anything, the game even discourages you from doing that, as the constant, unskippable need to type out each dialogue choice character-by-character and wait through Emily typing gets really really tedious.

Oh but this review is more than a few joke sentences, not like the really top tier reviews for this game.

reviewText:
This game is excellent.

Each and every one of us can vividly recall someone who at one point meant everything to us, but is now just a distant memory. Emily is Away recounts the tale of a young man who is transitioning beyond high school and moving onwards into college life. He feels a multitude of emotions - excitement about moving off to a brand new place and learning new things, happiness about getting into the school he desired and being able to start an awesome new adventure in his life, and lastly, a small, neverending tinge of sorrow deep within his heart when he thinks back to his former best friend from high school, Emily.

The game encompasses 5 years of this person's life, quintessentially, his entire college experience. As time progresses, people change. People move in and out of each other's lives every day. Someone you may have spoken to every day back in high school may be a distant memory now. In this game, you play the role of the young man described earlier and engage in multiple AIM-like chat conversations with your old friend Emily. These conversations are intermittent between each year, meaning that a lot of time passes in between each one, and therefore, both you and/or Emily may have changed a little during the time prior. This can be seen in the alterations in Emily's biography on the chat interface and her profile picture changes, as well as the stories she tells throughout the conversation while you catch up with one another's busy lives.

I won't get into too many details and will try to avoid spoiling anything for you, but I must say that the game does an excellent job of portraying the young and naive communications between a boy and a girl who may or may not have intertwined feelings for one another hidden within each keystroke. Whether or not this is the case is up to you and Emily. The dialogue choices you make throughout the game will effect what you learn throughout its course. I emphasize the word learn" in this case because just like in real life
date: there may be thoughts or feelings that this person on the other side of the screen feels towards you which are not made clear - perhaps because you never ask them
recommended: or perhaps because they are too scared to tell you. Whether you seek to learn Emily's feelings about you or not is your choice. Every sentence spoken by both Emily and me felt like it was substantial and had some sort of consequence on our relationship (not a romantic relationship
voteText: and that is one of the many things that I just loved about this game.\n\nEmily is Away is an impeccable embodiment of the human condition. Each of us has a special person like Emily in our life

In the end, I stopped feeling bad for the guy, I started hating Emily, and everything about the storyline. The narrator was one of those dudes that cries about the friendzone, which is just pathetic, and the girl he's obsessed with is just an annoying hypocritical ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. If this game had choices that ACTUALLY mattered, I'd recommend this, but I'm not recommending a game with crap characters and a man who feels sorry for himself because he decided to waste his time on a girl that is obviously selfish. Overall, the game ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• me off and if you want to play a game only to finish it feeling terrible in every single way, then this is definitely the game for you.

reviewText:
SPOILER ALERT!

I played through this game and enjoyed it, I found myself getting invested and actually cared about Emily and the crap she had to go through. When I finished the game, I was even saddened that she got back with her abusive boyfriend. I would have reccomended it...

THEN I PLAYED THROUGH THE GAME A SECOND TIME

I was understandably ticked that none of the choices I made in this game mattered even slightly in the long run. I decided not to go to the party, so she wouldn't end up with that abusive prat Brad. She ends up with Travis instead, who also happens to be an abusive prat. No matter what choices I made, the story went in pretty much the same direction as the first time I played through it. It also finally kicked in to how emotionally manipulative Emily really is.

In conclusion, I cannot reccomend this game. The Steam description claims that your choices determine the outcome of the story, but the outcome is always the same no matter what choices you make. When I thought that my choices mattered, I found the game much more enjoyable, but now it just leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

(Also, for the record, using trademarked/copyrighted material in your game is a good way to get sued. Just saying.)

reviewText:
Cheesy early 2000s references, a bitter romantic plot that has little interactivity, and, of course, a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• ending.

SPOILERS: DON'T READ IF YOU CARE ABOUT A FREE STEAM GAME

So basically you pick a screenname (foxygrndpa69) and your real name (lol I'm not putting that in here) and you talk to a chick named Emily who likes Coldplay and parties. You can either go to a party with her or, if you're dumb, you can stay home. After going to the party to hook up with her, time skips and know you're in college. Over the college years, you find out you had the chance to kiss Emily at the party but you didn't you dumb ballsack, so now she's all alone. Except she's wanting to visit! So you let her visit because you're not that dumb, but you find out later she wanted something to happen then, but your lazy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• still didn't do anything! Later, close to college gradutation, you talk for the last time, as everything meaningful you attempt to say gets deleted and changed into boring questions about the weather (an actual question that pops up). Eventually you have to say goodbye and the game ends.

The game acts like your choices have impact later in the story, but not really. I said coldplay was ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on my second playthrough, and so she doesn't start a conversation about music in the next chapter. Woo. A small conversation that had no impact on the plot was changed because I called her favorite band (at the time) ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. The plot stays the same no matter what minor conversation you have.

The plot itself is a bit on the lame side. This chick Emily totally wants you, but she goes out with some tool named Brad twice in the story, then whenever you get the chance to do something, the protagonist (offscreen by the way) ruins everything. You both want each other, and you both know you want each other, but you can't bring yourself to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• her. The plot is a sad story aimed to make people who fail in relationships think about themselves, and while I fail at relationships constantly, I can't seem to like this story. I know why my relationships fail, because I'm not dumb (if you want to know, message me your life story, and I'll get back to you). I don't want a romance story telling me I failed again, I want one telling me it's going to be okay, with a happy ending that doesn't paint me as a dumbass. If I end up making a game like this (totally possible) I will probably put it on GameJolt or Steam so everyone can feel good about themselves.

I suppose I should talk about the gameplay
date:
which is choosing an option and typing it. I mentioned already why the choices are bad, so I won't do that again, but the typing is probably one of the only cool things in this game. You pick a choice, then you mash the keyboard and predetermined words show up. I would have liked it better if I could have made than an option instead of the default, but oh well.

Also there are no options. I wanted to turn the volume down because it felt a bit loud and my ears are a bit sensitive, but there's no options menu.

This game is barely worth the 56mb it takes on my hard drive. I would rather fill up that 56mb with low resolution porn, because it would be actually worth my time.

reviewText:
Do you remember the late 90s? A time of .GIF filled websites, AltaVista and America Online or AOL as it was more commonly known. Back then everything was big and proud and come 2001 it all got bigger and prouder as Windows XP hit us squarely in the jaw with its big blue windows and incredible OS power. It was around this time that AIM, AOL‚Äôs Instant Messenger service was at its biggest. We all had an AIM username and like mobiles today we all sat there furiously typing away to friends and workmates over our monitors. We made relationships and we broke hearts, we arranged meets and gaming sessions. AIM was king.

To do this you have conversations with Emily about various aspects of yours and her life, from music to video games, movies to social anxieties and more. The game is a simple one to play. Emily pops up in AIM and says hello, which leads you to a multiple choice of answers. By picking your answer you then ‚Äòconverse‚Äô to Emily by pressing random keys on your keyboard. It may sound overly simple and even dull but rest assured, it is not. It feels like you are having a conversation with a real person and in this the developer, Kyle Seeley, really must be praised. Emily will annoy, tempt, tease and laugh along with you for all of its 45 minutes average gameplay per session.

Emily feels so real that at the end of my second playthrough I was desperate to make her fall in love with me but by the end of the fifth I was content to insult her and be as cold as a person in love can be to the other that constantly scorns her/him no matter how hard he/she tries! Come my sixth attempt I just wanted to be loved by anyone and was quite relieved and happy to know that it was all just a game.

Emily Is Away is a game that pushes buttons, your own emotional ones and for something consisting of basic text and very little else it does a surprisingly good job of it. Sure, it may not work for everyone but anyone out there that enjoys interactive fiction, choice and consequence this will no doubt bring more than one emotion to the fore once you really get into the game and determine your goal.

Multiple paths exist so one session is unlikely to feel like the last or next one but you will probably find that five or six attempts is enough to have seen most of it. This is not a bad thing though as those five or six attempts will likely take up to three hours or more of your time and for a game that has no set price you cannot ask for much more.

Without giving away spoilers it really is quite hard to explain the things you will come across when playing and so this will, like the game itself, be a short but hopefully fulfilling review of a beautiful little title that everyone really should experience at least once.

reviewText: This is an interesting little piece of interactive fiction that takes place from 2002 to 2007, with all the narrative contained entirely in chat messages. The medium actually enhances the story, since you get to see everything your character types, whether it's actually sent or not. What you DON'T say sometimes provides more insight than what you do, which I find to be a cool addition. I also like how the various user profiles change as the years go on. Both of these features give a fair bit of life to what could otherwise have just been bland chatlog reading.\n\nMy only problem is that you're required to press keys to type out your character's messages, and it slows the game down a bit, especially when a message turns out to be much longer to type than its choice description would imply. Other than that, I find this game to be worth a play or two, especially with the multiple endings it provides. If nothing else, it's at least free, so I'd say go for it.

reviewText:
So, apparently they had texting in 2002. Who knew.

Okay now seriously.
I just played through this game in about half an hour and I am really, very impressed.

The atmosphere is amazing. Everything from the nostalgic profile icons to the desktop background and sound effects that we all know so well combine very well to make a truly realistic and believable setting for the game.

But there's more than that. This game's themes of how friends can come and go, and how one small decision can affect so much, are impressively thought-provoking and even profound, especially for a free game that can be played through in 30 minutes.

It's as immersive of a Windows desktop simulator that you'll find, and it's pretty fun too.

Highly recommended for the price, give it a try!

reviewText:
Starring your favorite millennial bands, DEATH CAB FOR CUTIE, GORILLAZ, COLDPLAY, NINE INCH NAILS, MUSE, LINKIN PARK and MORE (because what else encapsulated the early 2000's better than your favorite bands), Emily is Away has you in the role of a dude on the quest for ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• but not getting any in an immersive Windows XP chat room.

Struggle to survive the college life of the turn of the century and win the heart acknowledgement of your one true love bestfriend.

The game bends to you. In your playthrough, you will be presented with difficult decisions, like whether to participate in an art school, go out with friends to the movies, or deciding if you'd rather say howdy" than "hello."

Customize your chat to have it look the way you want to. Change the color of the text to acid fuzz green and change your user picture when you decide that you like 300 more than The Ring.

Interact with your contacts list and see each of your friends' souls in the form of song lyrics and never communicate with them in this realistically simulated environment.

SCORE: friend / zone
Sleeping pills don't sound so bad anymore."

reviewText:
Free to Play, Story, Indie, Simulation, Retro
If you perfer being alone this game is amazing, otherwise get to the salt factory.

ConceptProsConsGameplaySelectable choices that change narrative and perception of your characterNot enough choices that could lead to more communication with your crush..(asking for number etc)Covers a couple of years of your life Only chatting with a person your interested with once a year, is beyond ridiculous (at least by my standards)You are likely to have similar chats with people online I'm not being paid to be a therapist, so don't whine to me once a year and call me your friend Things typed out are often deleted, showing hesitance, and carefully selecting his words at times Not being able to type yourself is sort of lame, though understandable, since it would be complex, programming wise. SoundNice typing sounds that are fun to listen to when you are spamming keys that somehow translate into englishGraphicsAbility to change graphic colors for the font and background is a nice touch

Emily is Away had potential to be a interesting game, of how people can re-connect online, catch up on each others life and possibly reunite, but in the end, becomes a experience of feeling alone" regardless of what choices you make in life.

PS: Also

I do appreciate the message behind the game but just some in game executions were just kind of frustrating.  Like my first playthrough I showed no romantic interest in Emily through my dialogue options and did absolutely nothing to try to take advantage of her and then "the year passes" and it's like "why did you take advantage of me when I was vulnerable" like I had no choice.

I could also be frustrated at this game becuase I feel like all of the same things happened to me in real life as well.  Who knows.  Don't cling to the past and just move forward."

reviewText:
I hope Emily stays away, I won't miss her.

There's honestly not a lot to this game, you spend a few 'chapters' talking to this girl, each time you're given 3 reponses to choose from which is supposed to be a branching story.

But as the game goes on, you two become more distant no matter what you say or do, and in the end you just say goodbye and that's it, no matter what you say the game will always end like this, which makes it kind of pointless.

I don't know if I was supposed to feel bad for myself or this Emily person, or if there's a deeper meaning to this game, I just know that after my playthrough I really didn't give a damn.

But hey, it's free so give it a try, you might like it.

reviewText:
Nope, sorry, maybe some people are different, and I'm one of them.
=====Warning: Spoilers Ahead=====
This game was good at the start, reeling in to bring a sense of closeness with the character emily, which I'm assuming led to the eventual flow of the story. However, it's here where I think the game has it wrong.

In short, no matter what you do, what you say, Emily will always be out of arms reach. You can never be with this girl, and no matter how hard you try, how much you change, it will never happen. This is where I disagree. Of course a girl like this has been in many peoples lives. But for the most part, I don't think this should happen. Never ever.

This cat and mouse game should not happen to you, it either makes it or breaks it. And you control how that plays out. You can be head over heels in love with this girl, but there's a point in your life where you either tell her you love her, or sever the head and leave it to die (Figuratively, I'm not telling you to kill someone you can't hook up with. I don't need a felony on my hands.)[/] But the way this game forces you to avoid the topics mentioned above, in my opinion, preaches the wrong message. And should be taken with a grain of salt.
==
Now, I know people will disagree with this, but do remember, it's only my personal opinion.

reviewText:
If you had to pay something for this I wouldn't recommend it but its free and its interesting. Timely even.

I'm sure most humans in the modern world have had a relationship with another human (presumably) over the internet. Either with someone they have moved away from or met online. If not now then probably around the time this game is supposed to take place.

The sounds alone will send pings of nostalgia, dopamine and serotonin (hopefully) and not something depressing.

The story is a bit predictable though I thought it would end a lot darker than it did; and to be honest given the timeline, I think this conversation would've ended MUCH sooner than it claims.

My only real complaint is that you must actually type things even though for obvious reasons you cannot type anything you want as if you were talking to an AIMBOT like you actually were back then. You select a dialogue option and then it gets all telltale on you ‚ÄúEmily will remember that‚Äù and it forces you to press buttons on your keyboard and the predetermined thing shows up. I'll grant you that this is likely a sort of breaking the fourth wall mechanic, showing you misspellings and even more importantly a change of heart while typing, a realization in the way something might come across once its reread rather than the way it sounded in your head before you started typing. Anyways...

THE GIST
Its only about 30 minutes long. It seems to fall into the Cibele pool of instant messenger narratively driven style experiments. It's fine. I don't know.

reviewText:
I was recommended this game by a friend who knows I'm a big fan of story games, and since it was free I thought I'd try it out. Unfortunately, it struck a nerve that I've been having with games generally lately, and that's the false sense of choice that so many games have these days. When your game is a visual novel, when you're not selling it on graphics or gameplay but on the story told and the way you as a player can affect that story, then to have a game where your actions have no effect whatsoever is simply ridiculous.

Don't get me wrong, I understand the point they were trying to make, and I even agree with it (namely that  there are some people in your life who in spite of everything you do you'll never be able to have a relationship with just because the circumstances don't work out right). But creating that scenario in such an artificial way, by removing any real agency from the player, is pointless. The most obvious example for me was the fact that you can't choose to kiss Emily at the party. You can't sell me a game on it being an interactive experience where I make the choices about the story and then turn around and say 'oh but that choice would ruin my beautiful, carefully crafted story, so you don't get to make that one'. That's when it stops feeling like a story game and starts feeling like the creator couldn't get their novel published so they made a game instead.

I thought the story was OK and  I liked the old school design, and if not for the problem with the endings I might have made this a recommendation (I'd even have been happy if there were multiple endings that were essentially the same but took into account the choices made earlier in the game somehow). But as it is, it's not a game, just a story, and there are plenty of better stories than this out there. Seeing the same people who criticised Mass Effect for the way it ended praise this game is bizarre to me. Thumbs down.

tl;dr 10/10 Emily remembered that I didn't like Coldplay.

reviewText:
I'm not sure if this game was supposed to make me feel something or not but it ended up being really, really... dumb. I honestly have no idea what even happened between me and Emily. Apparently something happened, but because the exposition is entirely through dialogue I never found out. The dialogue eventually becomes so limited and clunky that the only emotion I felt was frustration with the writer. I'm not sure whether or not this game is trying to sell me some sort of social message or something but the only lessons I got out of it were:

1) Capitalization is important and you look like an idiot without it.
2) Social skills are important and you look like an idiot without them.
3) Exposition in storytelling is important and you look like an idiot without it.

Emily seems to suffer from what I call High School Sophomore Syndrome" where not only is she unable to express her emotions
date:
but she is also unable to express if she even has an emotion. But don't worry this can be easily treated by actually being able to talk to someone. See most people are under the illusion that you are the socially awkward character in this game. They're wrong. You AND Emily are the socially awkward ones. Now past this point I'll be talking about spoilers for whatever it is you call this.

Alright spoiler time.

"NONE OF YOUR CHOICES MATTER AND YOU ARE A TERRIBLE PERSON NO MATTER WHAT YOU SAY" is what this game politely screams in your ear. The problem this story throws at you is that you apparently have sex with Emily. No matter what you choose this happens. But the probem is that the very minimalist gameplay is used as a means of exposition. So afterwards you have no idea if the problem is that there was consent involved  or that she is just very confused about how she should feel about it. So I'm going to guess that it was the former of these two (since this game is trying to give a message). The problem is it wants you to feel bad for Emiy after this. So you do. The problem is that you are the defendant in this situation and you honestly end up having no idea what's going on if you choose to feel sorry the dialogue is so extremly wishy-washy that you have no idea what actually happened at all. It doesn't help that Emily also has no idea what happened either. Which in any other situation would convey that she herself is emotionally vulnerable and confused. But somehow this game just made it seem like she instead didn't know how to feel about hooking up with one of her friends. Which is an understandable and justifiable feeling. Except when one of the main characters has no idea what happened and the other one has the emotional comprehension of a sixth grader--and you are completely unable to tell which one of the characters is which. And when dealing with a topic like this its good to make the player attached to at least one of the main characters. Except by the time a game would have normally done that
recommended: you've already finished where the emotional confrontation was supposed to be.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: the game's minimalistic gameplay just make the story dance around the subject in a situation where it needs to take a definitive point of view. The dialogue becomes so extremely limiting eventually
voteText: where instead of it becoming a hopeless situation in which you (the player/main character) tries as hard as they can to fix an unfixable situation
helpfulPercent: it instead becomes a hopeless situation in which you (the player) becomes so frustrated with how idiotic you (the main character) are acting that the situation becomes unfixable only because there is literally nothing you (the player) can do to stop yourself (the main character) from acting like the aforementioned sixth grader."

reviewText:
Emily is Away is a short game, where you (re)live the good old time of the instant messaging with icons, with horrible sounds. You play Emily's best friend and for 5 or 6 years, you're going to see this relationship evolve depending on your choices during the discussions. You begin at the end of high school until finishing college.

If there is something that you should know is that there is no happy ending. Well, I mean, you can be as nice as you, as much as responsible, trying to please Emily and the result will be always the same: she'll call on you. At the end, you can see that life changed you both.

You can clearly see that your character was crushing on Emily, however, you don't know if she's feeling the same. You don't have any control on outside events, like Travis's party or what happened between you and her during the week-end after she broke up with her boyfriend.

However, it's frustrating to try different routes. Each end of the discussion is Emily is away. You tell her that you can miss a group project reunion, a party with your friends, etc.. so that you can listen to her and she's rejecting this offer for example.

The fact is that Emily is Away is just a game made for nostalgic people. You just press enter to see the text you're writing (even correcting faults) and you choose your answer just before among three proposed. Some of them will not change the course of the discussion, others are important.

The only real fun thing to do is to try many usernames, to unlock new icons. I would even say that some may be not belonging to this era at all (Portal, Undertale and others). Another funny thing is to look at everyone's profile and remember when you were putting quotes or lyrics everywhere.

But it's not because it may become boring after a while that Emily is Away isn't worth a shot. It's reflecting life as it can happen, missed opportunities and relationships. It's always interesting to see that and besides, like I've said, it's also for nostalgic people, though I'm not feeling a nostalgia wave.

The graphics aren't bad at all. It's really well-chosen for what the game will want to do. As for the soundtrack, apart the infamous Windows sound and the ping, you don't have anything.

My only problem is that the cursor isn't pointing on where you want, I needed to click on the left of a button to manage to play - it has caused me a problem the first time I've played it as I thought it was stuck. I suppose it's a problem due to the a wider monitor than the game can handle.

Emily is Away is a good little game in the end and as it's free, your wallet will not cry for money.

reviewText: The stylistic and writing are decent, but it really doesn't branch enough. I wouldn't really recommend a second playthrough but the first is worth a little of your time.

reviewText:
Okay so I played through the game and it's a good idea, but I feel it was executed poorly.

The decisions you make towards the beginning of the game are thrown at you with no context because you and the girl you're speaking to have a backstory that needs to be forced onto you. Because of this I felt no connection with 'Emily' at all.
You're given names of people you've not heard of before, and the options towards these people are usually calling them a name or asking emily to treat them badly. Personally I didn't like this feature.
This sort of game relies on emotional attachment but the game failed to deliver that.

(Spoilers)
Emily is Away has no happy endings. Either way, the game will guilt trip you for your decisions. I personally frown upon this in a story-reliant game if it isn't done extremely well.
(Spoilers)

However, I do love the nostalgic aesthetic to the game. It's what made me want to play this game. It really brings back old memories!
The way the character and Emily types is very similar to what people of that age would send back then.

This would be much better with an internet friend or a first time talking scenario, as the user would be building the story as they go along rather than basing everything from a pre-determined story.
Emily is Away would probably get away with this if it wasn't as short.

Oh and the typing gimmick? H E C K that.

5/10, needs work.
+1 for being free, though.

reviewText:
Relive the early 2000s and your high school/college days with the following features:
-AIM!
-Coldplay, Good Charlotte, and Snow Patrol lyrics!
-MEAN GIRLS BUDDY ICON!
-Choosing an art college!
-That one girl that always beat around the bush, expected you to make every move, then chastised you when you finally DID make a move after having previously complained that you never made that move! That's okay, though, because she ended up marrying some scumbag anyway and all she does is sit around her house and do nothing but snapchat you pictures of her daughter and her cat all day even though you wish she'd just leave you alone and drop it already!!

11/10 for accuracy

If you're looking for an experience similar to Digital: A Love Story, don't come looking for it here.

The interface is great, but the story is severely lacking. Don't bother to play it multiple times, because every way it can pan out is frustratingly similar to how it does if you interact with Emily in a completely different way.

If you've got twenty minutes to kill slamming random keys on your keyboard, though, by all means.

reviewText:
Maybe about two hours long if you are really slow at finding all the endings.
You barely have any control over the story since most of the options are either the same thing or lead to the same dialog.
Emily is boring with no interesting traits other than being an angsty collage student. Everyone else has nothing (other than your character who from the dialog options is assumed to be a total beta).

The ending is supposed to be realistic" but all of the characters are so borring and get so little development you just don't care.

Gameplay itself was just chosing an option and mashing your keyboard until it typed it out so you could send (which got old quick).

The graphics are badly designed in that they made it pixel art for some reason instead of just trying to imitate XP.

The only "fun" part in this "game" was picking your avatar and name and watching how she reacts.

I don't know if you can even call this a game. I mean
date: at least in VNs you can have bad endings!  If you want a branching story
recommended: play a VN or a telltale game. This is a waste of 40 minutes."

reviewText: This is by far one of the most interesting games I have ever played. This is definetely one of my new favorite games, and an easy recomendation to my friends.

reviewText: Out of all of the titles that I have played and reviewed, this is definitely the one that proves that Steam needs to implement a neutral/mixed option for recommending games. Emily is Away is a very short narrative game, which takes you back to the good old days of AIM (AOL Instant Messanger). If I were to say that this game succeeds at anything positive at all, it would definitely the nostalgia factor it induces.\n\nThe objective of the game is simple, you chat with your friend" Emily over AIM chosing from various options of dialog to send in response to Emily's messages to you; The options you chose determine the events that happen in the upcoming chapters in the story
recommended: for a game that relies mostly on it's narrative and storyline
hoursPlayed: there aren't many options to chose from or many different routes to take.\n\nI won't spoil the story or the events for anybody
voteText: but if you were an avid user of AIM
helpfulPercent: MSN

reviewText: Out of all of the titles that I have played and reviewed, this is definitely the one that proves that Steam needs to implement a neutral/mixed option for recommending games. Emily is Away is a very short narrative game, which takes you back to the good old days of AIM (AOL Instant Messanger). If I were to say that this game succeeds at anything positive at all, it would definitely the nostalgia factor it induces.\n\nThe objective of the game is simple, you chat with your friend" Emily over AIM chosing from various options of dialog to send in response to Emily's messages to you; The options you chose determine the events that happen in the upcoming chapters in the story
recommended: for a game that relies mostly on it's narrative and storyline

reviewText: 2015 has been an awesome year in gaming and I was quite sad that Microsoft was letting go of the classic operating system Windows XP. God, I still have that startup themesong stuck in my head. I was quite happy about this game for giving me some nostalgic memories from Windows XP. But yeah, if you haven't played the game it's basically about these two characters that talk to eachother through a messaging program on the computer. It's starts out in 2002 when they're seniors in high school, and then ends off with them about to graduate from College in 2006. This another one of those games where you have to chose what you have to say, and whatever you chose can affect the story in different ways. The whole game isn't anything special or anything, just two individuals talking about what they're doing currently in their lives. But what I do like about the game is that it can often be relatable. Something that the game could've done better in my opinion is maybe make the characters say more interesting things, or create some gossip. Just something to spice up the game a little. But don't expect much since this is only a Free2Play game. Don't get me wrong, I did like the story, but a little simplistic if you want to create a game.\n\nAnother nice feature to the game are the icons. Every year in the game has a different profile picture icon, with things from that year, like 2004 being the year of American Idiot, or 2006 being the year 300 came out. You can also chose what name and screen-name you want which I highly like, because if you write the name Portal, or Isaac, you can chose to have that icon and you'll get an achievement. What made me crack up even more is when Emily actually comments about the icon. My absolute favorite which I recommend you trying is using the screen-name JohnCena. If you chose that, Emily will then ask you who this is, and your character will start saying JOHHHHNNNNN CENNNNAAA with the theme song playing in the background. Absolutely hilarious. Any bugs? Well, yes. If you type your name it will sometimes accidentally switch to the second line and it's really annoying trust me. But in the end, I would the game a thumbs up!

reviewText:
Emily is Away is a unique game within the Steam store, but it does have a few pull backs making you want to exit the game within minutes.
I will go through the following errors and issues I have with the following game Emily is away, there can be good things and there can also be bad things about the game.

There will be a mixture of both in the list below.

Too short- The game itself is great until you go past Chapter 2, it just gets a little boring and the game slows down making it almost impossible to reach Chapter 3 without sleeping or atleast clicking the X button to close the game.

Too repetitive- The game can be too repetitive in each chapter there is always an issue but you can only chose so many choices most of them pop up again and again which can mainly be seen in the chapters 3-4-5.

The game messes with you alot- I found this pretty funny when you first encounter the troll, but when you select options like Can we talk about things?" it would type it in but remove the question and ask something completely different ruining the game alltogether- which can be annoying especially if you want a different ending in the game.

No control of the game (Which continues from The game messes with you alot) - You barely have the chance to play the game or explore the game
date: it would only give you a few seconds showing your friends list before the chat opening
recommended: I believe there should be an option to minimise the chat to explore for example an old Windows xp desktop with pre-loaded apps.\nMaybe a little game but
hoursPlayed: it is so limited you can only click and press any button to progress into the game.\n\nOverall?
voteText: I would rate this game a 5/10 sort of in the middle since I did enjoy the game but the game itself had a bit of flaws holding me back from giving it a high rating in this review."

reviewText:
Story rich? Sure, the game is basically a short book, but with a finger workout.
Simulation? Well, it LOOKS like an early 2000's computer, but you can't actually do anything with it.
Retro? Yay, more pixel games! Very rarely done concept! Original!
Indie? Obviously. How else would you get attention without a tag like that?
Free to Play? The correct way to go, since this wouldn't be worth a dime. (Although there is a donations link..)

This is the kind of thing you would find on Newgrounds years ago, and it could easily give the same story experience without making you pretend to type the words you don't choose to say. How anyone could possibly consider this to be a legitimate game is dumbfounding. Go read a book.

reviewText:
**SPOILERS**







Emily is Away is a wonderful game where you relive all of your cringy beta memories (or live them out for the first time) and talk to a girl over instant messenger who you will never have.
You can be a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to her, but that won't get you anywhere.
You can be really nice to her, but the beta protagonist you play will delete half of the messages and that won't get you anywhere.
You can get laid, but that'll make her feel weird.
You can stop her from hooking up with you, but that'll make her feel weird.
You can try to set boundaries so she won't hook up with you, but classic Emily wants what she wants, and that is to feel weird.
You can try to get with another girl, but that won't work out.
You can try to prevent her from getting with some d-bag, but that doesn't matter because she'll just get with some other d-bag.
You can try desperately to tell her how you feel in the end, but the beta protagonist won't allow himself to say what he needs to.
So in the end, you lose.
Every. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing. Time.

And that's it. That's the game. There is no secret formula to a happily ever after ending. Your decisions don't matter. In fact you should just give up. Shut the game down. Shut your computer down. Blow your computer up. And focus on the things that are more important in your life, like alcohol abuse and making sure things like this don't actually happen to you.

10/10 would suffer again.

reviewText:
Free short multiple-choice dialogue game.

This game gave me a heart-wrenching half an hour on my first play-through and a bittersweet 30 minutes on the second. You get to have 5 dialogues with Emily, each roughly a year apart, covering the time from right before high school graduation through right before college graduation. As additional touches you get to choose your IM icons and can read the status messages of your buddies.

Emily is a friend you've grown attached to during high school, and you stay in touch with her during college. Dialogues consist in Emily talking to you, and you get a choice of 3 answers that you then need to type out (hitting any keys, very satisfying if you can't type). As you make choices, you're influencing the future plot of the game.

If you like stories with feelings, you need to play this at least once. Did I mention it's free?

reviewText:
This game is probably appealing to many, but it reminded me way too much of what high school romance is like (Even though they are supposed to be in college). This game left me rolling my eyes, recognising all the dramatic subtext that I probably used myself at that age. This game also left me feeling dirty  as if Emily was insisting I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• or took advantage of her, when the entire game I remained aloof and as uninterested as I could be! It made me even more mad, because I felt it was SHE who was being pushy about coming out for the weekend. She was obviously on the rebound.

I don't know, maybe teens will get more appreciation from this game. Maybe even some adults.

This is just one of the most disatisfying waste of time games I've played to date. On the plus side, I got all of the achievements in 40 minutes.

It is lovely. An experience I'll remember for sure. One of my favorite titles I've played this year. Bravo. Bravo."

reviewText:
Product received for free

People are just the worst, you know that?! You try being a nice guy, being caring and considerate and honest and what they need when they need it and get them drunk so you take advantage of them in their vulnerable state and bang them, and then Brad comes along and ruins everything.

F*CK YOU, BRAD!

Here they've actually managed to turn instant messaging into a game, and you know what?... It's actually pretty good! Played out over five chapters and five conversations spanning five years during high school and college, shoot the sh*t with Emily online and put your relationship through trials and tribluations of friendship, jealousy, rebounds, hook-ups, awkward aftermaths, consolations and, well... you'll have to play to find out the rest of what's involved.

As the conversations play out you are given dialogue options. Click on the one you like the look of, hammer random keys on the keyboard to make the message type itself out on the screen, hit Enter, then watch the story unfold. There really is nothing more to the game except to try and make the best of each hand you're being dealt. Just like in real life!

I really don't want to get into any more of it and spoil how things play out, but it is strangely affecting and relatable and, while I can't speak for everyone, I personally found it a little too close to home in hitting its mark. And I guess that will also play a big part in how you feel about the game and whether you like it or not. If the text all rings true to you then it will really impact you. If it all seems totally foreign to you then it will just seem like dumb writing with stupid people making stupid decisions. But sometimes that's actually just what life is really like.

It's free, it's only about 30-40 minutes to play through, and it's a really touching, true-to-life tale of relationships and people that's totally worth checking out. And if nothing else, I think we can all learn a very important, valuable lesson from it - Brad is a total d*ck. Eurgh, I HATE HIM SO F*CKING MUCH!

reviewText:
One of the most gut-wrenching games I've played inawhile. Probably because it hit really close to home for me.
Take a trip down memory lane as you chat with the one who got away.
Nicely designed with a nostalgic AOL IM design. The character of Emily is pretty well written too.
Quick to play and free too!

I had a girl who I loved once. This game was a reminder to me of how some things are truly never meant to be. How time can rot away a relationship. How sometimes we as guys constantly mess up. How naive we were, and still are, as young adults. There is no way to get Em to love you, just as how theres nothing I can do to get my old friend from HS to love me. There are no good endings, there are no bad endings, just the realistic ending.

I'd be lying if I said I didn't want to cry while playing.

Tell the girl in your life you love her. Don't ever let her go.

reviewText: The entire game is a really annoying gimmick. There are no choices that you can actually make, only the illusion of them; every branch of dialogue reaches a singularity by the next chapter. The choices you make also have varying degrees of power, and lacked consistency. Sometimes it seems like the game wanted you to shape what choices your character had made prior to the game, or outside of the AOL chat, but at other points, when it was convenient to the plot, you had no say in what you did. Sometimes the choices were literally the same thing with a few words changed. The tapping on the keys to type was also very annoying and pointless.

reviewText: There are some games that are breathtaking from the moment you open them up. They are visually stunning and they engage with you mechanically in a way that is visceral and immediate. Journey, Transistor and Bastion are all games like that for me. Then there are games that excite you conceptually. They are minimal offerings but what they lay bare is so creatively exciting that it brings a smile to your face. This smile persists even while the narrative unfolds in melancholic tones. The experience is one of beauty and sadness as so intrinsically related. Gone Home, Papers Please, and Emily is Away are games that have felt like this for me. Emily is Away brilliantly captures all the ineptitude of adolescent and early adult relationships in a digital age where connection is so easy, but so fragile. From the limited response options, to the fumbling way in which each message is crafted, deleted and recrafted, the game captures the anxious experience of trying to love, be loved, express love, care, whatever. The game is also clever in the way it aligns your expectations as a video game 'player' with the hopes and aspirations of your avatar. You, the player, actually want to win Emily over, because you believe it aligns with some notion of 'winning' in a sense external to the game. I cannot wait to try to win Emily over again and to be heartbroken and reminded of all my past mistakes once more.

reviewText:
Recommending this for anyone looking for a quick and easy 100% achievement title. The main game is extremely short and can be finished in a very brief single sitting, with the remaining achievements being easter eggs that arepretty self explanitory looking at the achievement list. The easter egg achievements can all be done in about 5-10 minutes after completing the main game.

As for the game itself...

Emily is Away is a text based game revolving around 2 high school friends who try to keep in touch during college. Both have feelings for each other. Stuff happenss, or stuff doesn't happen. No matter how you play the game, the ending pretty much remains the same. It actually has a cool premise, as the game is played out entirely in instant messaging. It's a very brief game, and there is nothing much to do other than to read what Emily types, and progress the game with one of 3 choices at every response. Do the choices really matter? Well, not so much. It changes the flow of everything, except the ending. Not to say there is not just 1 ending. There is more than 1 ending. But the ending is usually always going to be... Well. Just play and see.

Not my usual type of game. And if not for the achievements, I probably would have skipped it.

reviewText:
Full Review
‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ ‚Äì 4/5 ‚Äì Like & Recommend

Total Cost: $0.00 ‚Äì 100% Free to Play
Estimated Time to Complete 1 Playthrough: 30 minutes
Achievements: Yes ‚Äì 20 achievements available
Trading Cards: Yes ‚Äì 5 cards per 1 set

Emily is Away" is a nostalgic throwback for anyone who ever used AIM
date: and particularly for those who were in high school or college during their AIM usage.\n\nThe interactive story follows conversations between you and protagonist Emily over the course of 5 years (2002 ‚Äì 2006)
recommended: exploring your relationship from your senior year of high school together
voteText: and ending with your final year of university. When talking with Emily
helpfulPercent: you are given a variety of choices to respond and react with
votesHelpful: which are either positive
votesTotal: negative
votesFunny: or neutral; these responses will shape future interactions with Emily throughout the game. Spoiler: there is currently no known ‚Äúhappy‚Äù ending for you & Emily. Generally
commentsCount: it always ends in ‚Äúgoodbye‚Äù.\n\nUnlike similar games
column16: which are simply ‚Äúclick to proceed‚Äù
column17: ‚ÄúEmily is Away‚Äù continues to indulge players with a nostalgic and realistic experience by requiring you to ‚Äútype‚Äù (or pretend to type) your selected responses. This aspect
column18: as well as those mentioned below
column19: truly heighten the experience.\n\nIn addition to its story
column20: the game offers fun little features such as changing your font during chat with a variety of possible combinations
column22: and changing your own profile icon! Perhaps the most enjoyable features are the latter two
column23: which appropriately and humorously allude to that year‚Äôs most stereotypical messages
column25: and fandoms. For an added comedic experience
column26:
I highly recommend examining all of your friends‚Äô profiles and watching them as they change throughout the years; I promise you will not be disappointed!

TL;DR
‚ÄúEmily is Away‚Äù is an enjoyable game worth playing if you have ~30 minutes to spare and want a nostalgic experience or if you want free achievements."

Indeed I played Emily is Away with reasonable hype after the great reviews I read on the steam store.

The story of Emily fails in some crucial points I cannot honestly appreciate at all.

Due to the nature of the game, I won't present a TL;DR section.

Here we go:

Much like Fallout 4/Mass Effect, you'll be presented 3-4 dialogue options that BARELY affect the overall story arch.

Is that bad? Nope, as Emily does one thing very well: Making you want to experience every dialogue option to see the answers and different small talks you'll get in response.

It does fail as a story as it has a start and (an EXCELLENT) build up.... but SEVERELY lacks as an end. It just... ends. Yes, it's impressive how you get to CARE about characters that don't exist and most: do not even talk (game's just a chat window, literally).

But none of it goes ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing anywhere!

Apparently there are 2 endings: Mine was  Emily ends up going back to the boyfriend she broke up with 2 chapters or so ago. A boyfriend that had one hell of a temper and didn't hit her because her guardian angel was amazing! Both you and Emily end up talking occasionally after high school as the story happens during college and the tension between you and Emily is not only ridiculously clich√© but the fact that by the end it's CRIMINALLY linear completely kills the atmosphere of a tense story I was so excited for. Until the last chapter I was loving the game, and then... ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• starts getting talked about and I pick an option, as my character DELETES MY DIALOGUE and WRITES A NEW, LAME AND 1-WORDED DIALOGUE like Goodbye"
date:
"I dunno".

The chance of a real "relationship" with this virtual character/setting the mood for a great emotional story is completely skull ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed by this as every choice I make is quickly deleted and replaced with something that is answered for the sake of the ending being "always bad". All stories can end well.

Not this one!

Any questions of the story
hoursPlayed: but overall I thought the ending (while realistic (then again
voteText: other realistic endings could've happened)) was rushed and literally went nowhere. Just a story of a  missed chance at love that generated a weird relation between 2 friends of the opposite sex that ended their friendship by the end of college\n\nAnd as I do not see my choices mattering at all to the course of the story
helpfulPercent:
I cannot even care for the second ending as I also don't see it being any conclusive.

Other Stuff and Overall ~
A good game? Yes. Totally worth a playthrough and an achievement run as I got it 100% in like 40 minutes. The game itself can be completed in 25-30 minutes. It's charming
votesHelpful: interesting and quite well done.\n\nIt just lacks more branching paths that would allow for a good ending that cannot happen because sometimes your choices are replaced by others totally different (Didn't people complain about that in Fallout 4? This did even worse and get's nearly praised its ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off!)
votesTotal:
ending in a forced note that left a very sour taste in my mouth that I had to wash with proper dialogue options in an RPG.

It's a free-to-play 60 Mb game. Definately worth a run. I sincerely hope for a sequel or a similar game but that allows for your choices to matter instead of this.

A rock solid 7/10. Hit the sweet spot on everything but the ending which killed the experience for me."

reviewText:
Emily is Away is an... interesting game indeed.
This is one of those games I can't decide if I should or should not reccomend it, but the fact that it is a free experience, and that for the first run, at least, I think that makes it worthwhile for an hour or two time waster.

Tl;DR: The game has an amazing premise but the thing that spoils the experience is the ending, while pretending to have multiple endings there is really only 1 with variations and it spoils the idea of choice. A good and bad ending should have been implimented, maybe not full hate or full love, but at least one that lets you keep in touch or one where she is very hurt and decideds to end the friendship herself, something to make it seem worthwhile and give each choice some heft.

Full Review:

The Premise of EiA is that you live the life of a boy who is friends with Emily, and the two of you interact with an interesting story crossing a 5 year span from 2002-2006 where you both grow up trying to stay in contact, but ultimately failing by the end. The idea is the whole its not the destination

reviewText: I wasn't planning on doing a review on Emily is Away, but after my 4th playthrough with the same (similar) outcome I just HAD to. If you played through this at least once you could immediately tell how shallow, uninteresting and broken Emily is. The reaction of the player to the dialogue (very limited) left me feeling furious about how much of a spineless tool he is. In case you didn't get it by now, this is the ultimate friendzone simulator - and she's not even worth the, what, 4 years of senseless back and forth. She won't make up her mind, she's whiny, clingy and oblivious, ALL in the span of a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing 5 minute IRC CHAT CONVO. This girl acts like a 12 year old ALL throughout college. She even gets worse with time. If you played at least a couple of simulation games or dating sims, you KNOW how cheesy/brainless these dialogue options can be - except these always lead to the same outcome (just more or less frustrating to read).\n\nNow, I know what you're thinking. Why am I being so rough on an indie sim game that you can easily walkthrough in 10 minutes? Cause I feel like it could have potential. I was a teenager during these years. I listened to those bands and posted those cheesy lyrics and got all the refferences. The soud and ambiance really threw me back a d√©cade and I feel like it could have been something cool. But, damn, all the characters were ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and I wish I could have dumped Emily right of the bat.

reviewText:
Emily is Away is a really good, short story driven game and yes it's worth your time.

Emily is Away is a really simple game. You play as yourself as you talk to Emily over a chat room window. The game takes place over the period of 5 years and believe me when I say this game is an emotional train.

This game is incredibly simple. You can pick one of three different options and then you decided on how you want to talk to Emily and then you bash your keyboard to simulate typing. It's all really simple.

The game graphics are simple as it's a pixel style Windows XP operating system.

There isn't much I can say about this title due to the very small size of the entire project. It took me only 30 minutes to finish the entire thing, it might take longer for people who want to see the different outcomes, but in the end it's still really short.

Emily is Away is a great title and I suggest everyone to try it out. It's emotional and it's incredibly well written. I want to stay away from spoilers so I won't write anymore, just go and play the game right now.

Final Rating:
7.5/10 - Worth Playing

If you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about the review.

For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
'Emily is Away' is a truly relatable game out there for those who deal with unrequitable love in their life. It has not only evoked my emotions, but has also made me realize how truly sad it is when you love someone yet they do not love you back, and this game is an epitome of that reality, infact, my reality to be precise. You only know how much you really love someone once you see them love someone else. Nonetheless, this brilliant game corellates to exactly how my love life is like, and how it may be like for the rest of its lifespan: Forever Alone.

+ Evokes Emotions
+ Great for those who deal with unrequitable love
+ Relatable

- Not enough possibilities to endings

--VERDICT--
Grade: A+
Score: 9.5/10

Recommended ‚úì

reviewText:
Emily is Away is an interactive story. A text-based interactive story. (It's important to remember this)

It has very nice information about the characters hidden in the details to explore if you want, but overall it's a pretty simple game, an Instant Message simulator like those back in the Windows XP era (same sound and graphics too, that's cool).

The control is interesting when playing for the first time, but it turns to be super annoying when we try to explore the game for a second gameplay. It doesn't give the same immersion like the first time, but I think this is the story's fault...

===| SPOILER ALERT |===

It may be a spoiler down here so consider play it now, since it's free anyway.

So, the story... It is okay... But the decisions you have in the game are almost totally worthless. It's feels like doesn't matter if you care or not about Emily, and that's pretty sad. You will say something than the game tells that Emily will remember that" and it never is used again
date:
neither change anything. I was super disappointed in my second try to see the other options.

===| SPOILER ALERT END |===

I do recommend this experience
hoursPlayed: what you'll lose if you play?)\n\nI also recommend to do not try play it a second time for any reason. Keep what the game give you for the first time and move to the next one. Works better this way

videos and images even though i had a sh*tty internet connection and spent hours just typing like mad. When it all kind of went away I wasn't really aware of how much I am going to miss it.
When i started playing this game it all started coming back to me. And it felt so good.

And then came the inevitable

reviewText:
In this game you play as a character who is essentially Zyzz in an alternate universe where he didn't begin to feign confidence or eventually forfeit his life while on the journey for optimal aesthetics. The complete anithesis to all that Zyzz came to stand for upon his unfortunate, early demise.

As Zyzz, while you can't seek gains, eat chicken for protein or shred like you might expect, you can actually talk to a woman online. Now, this is where the game really picks up.

The game allows you to enter a screenname and your real first name. This is a cool little mechanic because at a glance it doesn't seem like much, but Emily will refer to you as your real name occasionally which is great for immerson. Unless you're like me and made your real name 'largecock'. Still, it was heartwarming when she said that I would ...always be largecock. =]" nonetheless. There are also nice references in the form of the display picture you choose which change depending on the chapter
date: which are good for a bit of a nostalgia-induced smile.\n\nIt's a simple game but the attention to detail is there. Sometimes you'll misspell words and have to correct them
recommended: sometimes the discussion becomes so contentious that you'll feel the need to rephrase. It's these little things that really reinforce the feeling that Zyzz is trying his hardest to kindle something between the two of them
hoursPlayed: albeit relatively unsuccessfuly throughout.\n\nSimple text-based games designed to evoke emotion are by no means new but for my money this is one of the better ones. Zyzz might be a bit of a beta (especially toward the end) and Emily might arbitrarily hold on to menial events for quite long but in the immortal words of Linkin Park which are
voteText: for me
helpfulPercent: intrinsically entwined with that Windows XP wallpaper and IM messengers which would now be considered ancient (yahoo 4 lyf add me on friendster) "In the end
votesHelpful: it doesn't even matter
votesTotal:
and in the end this game is a worthwhile for a playthrough at the least.

Also the steam screenshots on this game's page are pretty funny so that's cool.

reviewText:
I honestly don't know why people make this game a big deal. Also I've played this game before it was on steam so don't think I didn't play it.

The game is about a guy who presumably wants to date a certain very averege girl name Emily (which in my opinion doesn't have that many redeeming qualities for the main character (you) to go after... But hey everyone has their own thing I guess..) and your jurney to uh... well without spoiling...uh... you're just a lame person okay? Nothing advances, nothing happens and you as a player can't do anything about it because it's not a game..
This isn't really a game because nothing changes as you literally just press one of 3 or 4 options that have absolutly no difference to them and you get the same boring ending each time.
The game also tries to be TellTale because every little thing you do is like Emily will remember that" Emily doesn't give a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• bro nothing changes xD
I think this game would be super emotional for guys who had little to no interaction with girls before (which I don't bash it's just how I see it) and are really thirsty for that kind of thing.

Don't get me wrong though
date: for the developer I'm sure it was more of a self reflection nostalgia piece of art but as a game (and yes
recommended: even though it's free) it just doesn't work and in all honesty unless you are some "forever alone" kid who complains about being friendzoned and whatnot you will see that the story kind of feels....Dull? I am saying that because if I were in the main character's shoes I would've done things way differently. The fact that you can't do things your way (or even kind of your way) makes me just look at this whole thing as a story about a guy (the dev I'm assuming) who had trouble talking to a girl back in the day.\n\nAgain no hate for the dev
hoursPlayed: it's just that his doesn't work as a game in my opinion. The (let's call it) novel is free though so if you got time to burn then why not? Just don't expect something amazing out of it."

reviewText:
In Emily is Away, you play as a beta orbiter unable to pick up on social cues and mentions, who is attempting to desperately avoid the friendzone of what is otherwise a normal relationship between two people who just happen to be of a different gender.

There are twists, turns, band references, and pretending that after someone is already in a relationship that you can still salvage getting laid because you're a nice guy who tips his fedora intensely whenever something goes wrong which means you couldn't possibly be undesirable to hang around, especially because you like Blink 182 and Green Day and that must be what people are into. You could never relate however as this is pleb music for people with pleb tastes and you're more of a harsh noise, drone, and classical music guy and are above such lowest common denominator trash.

This is truly an emotional game, it really hammers home the pain of the fact that you will never be able to type as fast as the main character; A Masterpiece of an emotional roller coaster given high marks by top tier critics like Nathan Grayson of Kotaku and Brendan Caldwell of Rock Paper Shotgun. These people have had amazing insight into video games and they haven't led me astray yet, especially now. And it's free! You too can enjoy using a Windows XP themed Commadore 64 to simulate being friendzoned and getting subsequently angry that people Just don't get me
date: you know?"\n\nI look forward to future works by Kyle Seeley for he has demonstrated his ability to tell a compelling story."
