reviewText:
TL;dr  I hate Emily. She's manipulative. If you've ever been in a  relationship like this maybe it'd be more relatable and you'd like it, but I haven't so this whole story was very annoying.

-----------------------------------------------------
She is just working her way around to make you the bad guy -.- Then she guilt trips you like it's always your fault she is a dummy. Then if you say something to tick her off, she says the same thing later like some snarky butt. I really tried to be very nice to her but after I hanged out with her , then she ended up all pissy at me? Like what the heck is that about?

If you drop the topic she's better, but oh if you want to drop a topic she gets all pissy at you. This girl is backwards.

Anyways, only amusement was having the same name as her and pretty much choosing the most negative answer to everything she said. (Not like it mattered what you chose though because she would always find a way to find something awful about what you said)

I haven't had a relationship like this, so I can't relate, so I dunno. For those who have had a relationship like this, maybe you'd feel for it more and be more understanding of it? I'm not sure.

For a game to make you dislike a character, this is the game to choose.

reviewText:
Sadly this is my first game I'm not recommending.

Don‚Äôt read Story part if you‚Äôre interested in playing the game.
(Good thing that it's near the end :P)

Gameplay:
It's like the Tell Tale" games.You make decisions and "Emily will remember that".Pretty simple.The only stressful part is that you literally have to type to make the message appear too!Don't worry you don't need to even spell the words out when you choose a dialogue.You just need to spam your keyboard to make the dialogue appear.

Confuse?Allow me to make an example.

1.Hi
2.Sup!
3.Howdy!

Let's pretend you chose 1.
Now you have to type it out.
You spam your keyboard not even touching the words related to the dialogue.
Example you tap *the space bar*
Now "H" appears!
You tap the *space bar* again!
Now "i" appears!
Still confuse?You have to tap out the dialogue.Let's leave it at that.

Audio:
No music.Just keyboard tapping sounds and computer beeps.Etc.
Nothing special.

Story:
The story is about you (the reader) and a girl named Emily.You like her and she obviously like you too but won't admit it.The story goes from simple things like attending a party or not going to the party.Then it starts to get complicated because the choices becomes more stressful like either letting Emily visit you or just leave her in the dirt.You will soon have to have friendship problems with Emily as your choice will soon effect you.The bad thing is every choice you make in Chapter 3 and 4 will soon get to the very same awful ending.She will soon ditch you.There is no 'Good Ending" where she finds out you're a good guy and dates you.That's the stressful part.You doing everything you can to make her like you but in the end she doesn't even notice.

Overall:

Story: 5/10
Reason: It has it's up and downs.The story is entertaining and very simple.You will find yourself attached to it and wanting to play more and more of it.Then your dream gets demolished as every single choice you make (even good ones!) gets you the same horrible ending.No point in replaying the game hoping to get a "better ending".There will be only stress.

*Trust me I played this game for 1.8 hours
date:
longer than anybody else I know how stressful it is.*

Graphics+Audio: 8/10
Reason: It's simple.Nothing much.Nothing to expect out of it.It's pretty nostalgic if you ever used Windows XP.

And finally!The gameplay!: 7/10
Reason:It's pretty entertaining even though I didn't recommend it.I enjoyed playing it.It pass the time and killed my boredom.If you would play this I recommend just play it quick and then forget about it later.

Overall:20/30
Pretty neat game.I wouldn't recommend it if you like story games.It'll ruin your experience a lot.If you want to pass the time and kill your boredom
recommended:
then go ahead and play it.Don't say I didn't warn you.All in all it's just a game you wouldn't enjoy because of the story.But at least it'll give you a better understanding of life and girls.

Oh you're still here?Well let me give you a message.

Screw Emily
Screw Brad
Screw Travis
And rip dreams."

reviewText:
SPOILER FREE REVIEW

EDIT : Last review wasn't to original neither reflected anything about the game

TL;DR  It's a good time killer with some easy achievements
Introduction to the game

Emily is away, is an indie based on a relationship between Emily and you. During the years you may choose what to say to Emily ( A example: She likes Coldplay, she askes you if you like them, you can reply with : I like them. 2. They're ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. 3.Never heard of them.).

Based on the words you say to her, the game will have 2 endings: 1.The tough guy, who tells only bad stuff & all, or the sensible guy, who says how much he cares about her & stuff.....

Pros & Cons
+ Memes, just memes, you get to do the ANDHISNAMEISJOHNCENA achievement, something that I personally wanted on my Steam Wall for ages.

+ Good time killer, as i mentioned before, this is just a simulator where you talk to a girl, which can be either interesting or boring.

+ Easy achievments, thanks to this game I achieved my 7th perfect game, you get 6 achievments for finishing the game & the rest of them are just meme achievments.
+ It's FREE

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

- I wish the game had a better ending or an alternative ending, since the game leads to one ending only.

Overall raiting
Despite the ending not being the best, the game is very well developed for an indie
A solid 9/10

reviewText:
Enter to a very early 2000s Windows. Create a username, it can be anything you want. Then enter your real (or fake) name, so Emily may refer to you as that. Choose a icon (Changes each chapter).

Once you start talking to Emily, you get three options to choose from. After you choose your option type like a maniac until the message is done. If that doesn't tickle your fancy you may also change the COLORS of your text and background.

Sound exhilarating, right?

~~Well Emily is just a  mess.

Overall it does feel like you are talking to someone. A somewhat nice little free to play game. Give it a go.

reviewText:
*Some spoilers perhaps*

Interesting short-story game. Sort of like a visual novel, but interactive in a different (slightly annoying) way. You play a guy who is friends with Emily, a girl you clearly have feelings for in your senior year of high school, and you get to view some slices of life through their college years via a recreated AIM interface.

The sounds are incredibly nostalgic, hearing the door opening/closing sounds made me feel like I was really on AIM again for the first time in many years. Viewing your friends profiles and seeing the various song lyrics and typical things you'd find there is a nice touch too. The creator of the game certainly spent plenty of time on AIM back in the day.

I am not a fan of the fake-typing input that is used here. You pick one of 3 options to converse with, but then you must input the keys yourself. However, since you don't know what exactly is going to be typed, and you are just forwarding the script with random inputs, it essentially feels like you're playing HackerTyper or something. It would have been totally fine if they had just automatically typed in the responses for you once you picked your choice.

Watching the protagonist type in responses, erase them, and then reconsider his words is probably the most compelling part of the story. At first he is just correcting typos, but as you go into the story more, he starts completely rephrasing his words, and in the final chapter, you watch as he completely freezes up and stops writing what he means.

If you've ever talked to someone you had a crush on over AIM, MSN, or any other kind of chat program, this story may hit close to home for you. I wish there were some different endings, as you get a ton of different answer prompts throughout the game and it even notifies you that Emily will remember certain things you say, but it doesn't seem to make a difference at all.

Overall, it's free, it's short, and it's an interesting approach on telling a story of online-based (or at least, online-oriented) romance. Along with Cibele, I think this is an interesting trend of storytelling. It does have some flaws with the way it is played, but it's a neat game and one that I will remember.

reviewText:
My Impression:
I heard about this game from Twitch chat wanting multiple streamers to play it on their stream. That intrigued me so I decided to try it myself.

Positive:
+ Nostalgic, since my generation was the AIM generation where you would creep on peoples' bios ;)
+ Free

Cons:
- Too Short
- Limited choices (out of the choices given, I wouldn't have said any of them)
- No multiple endings
- Limited buddy icons, lol, if you're going to make a game specifically about AIM, at least have more choices of buddy icons

I guess I could say it's worth a play since it's so short, but you really wouldn't be missing anything if you never played it at all.

2/10

Still unsure why people wanted to watch streamers play this. Also, I'm unsure why there's so many positive reviews for this game.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
The game is short (about 2 hours for me), but it'll totally make you sad.

This game is nostalgic, because the conversations occur on something that looks like AOL Instant Messenger, which everyone used if they were a teenager in the early and mid 2000s.

The point of the story is to talk to a girl named Emily, who the player has romantic feelings for. Things get complicated no matter what you do. Lots of people wanted a good ending for this game, but I found it more fitting that there isn't one. Sometimes, situations in real life can have no good ending due to decisions made in the past.

Have you ever spoken to someone you had feelings for or at least really cared about on a messenger, and wanted to tell them how you truly felt? So, you carefully type it all out, but before you can hit send, you feel to scared of what might happen if they know the truth, so you delete it all, and say something far less meaningful?
Well, that's what you'd experience going through the story. A lot.

All of the other game references in the quest for icon achievements cheers you up at least, after you get through the story. My favorite references were Doge, Nyan Cat, and Undertale.

reviewText:
I am EffMe, first name Seriously.

I spend my time trying to talk to a friend who is very self-absorbed. I seem to have a cranial bleed from the frustration of pretending to care about this girl called Emily, and so I can only seem to think of three dialogue options, all of them contrived, out of place and thrusting me towards the narrative like a pervert near a playground.

My ability to be relatively upbeat and supportive without caring about this Tumblrette has me given the bad ending where I am forced to ask questions to someone who I don't care about. There is no option for okay"

reviewText:
OKAY, WELL, FIRST THINGS FIRST, EMILY: COLDPLAY IS ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING GARBAGE. Okay? Muse is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• too, and don't even get me started on Death Cab.
Now that we got that out of the way, let me tell you something: you and your impossible standards can go die in a fire. Take some responsibility for your actions, will you? You suggest coming over ONE WEEK after a break up, WHAT IN THE ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• did you think was gonna happen? At least I told you NOT TO BRING ALCOHOL, so at least you can't blame beer for your poor choices, can you?
Then I went back in time and told you NOT to come AT ALL, 'cause it would be bad timing. Which sounds pretty reasonable to me, but you resented me for it, because you didn't get anything out of that weekend while I was banging Emma. So how did THAT work out for you?
I'm always there to listen to you yap about Brad, that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing weirdo with a Donnie Darko obsession--I'm sure if you marry him he'll end up murdering you and the children, and committing suicide--then I was there to listen to you talk about that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Travis, who you even agreed was a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ucker. God, I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing hate Travis.
No matter what decision I make, you act like a god damn child. You make everything about yourself, and then when I finally have the strength and resolve to tell you I'm not gonna be your emotional crutch anymore, you say 'I should start thinking about people other than myself.' Isn't THAT ironic? Guess what, you idiot: I graduated with a major in engineering, I'm getting myself a great job, I'm gonna move on my own while you go live with Travis in a trailer park, I'm gonna make money, I'm gonna enjoy life a little while, then I'm gonna call Emma again and get married, we're gonna have some kids, and a nice house in the suburbs, and you're gonna wish you hadn't ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed me over across the space-time continuum.
Travis' hairline is gonna start receding when he's 25, just like his dad's. So ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you.

Great game, I highly recommend it. 28 Days Later is a great movie too, I hope you remember me every time it's on TV, you insufferable ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

reviewText: Overall it is a decent game however short. Yet the ending left me frustrated as no matter how many times I played I always got the same ending. The description indicates a branching narritive and you do see notifications such as 'Emily will remember that.' and 'You choose to go to the party.' yet I don't see any meaningful consiquences for those actions. Towards the end the game even removes your dialogue choices. You select an option to reply which is changed to something completely different. I get that there are certain parts of the game where the dialogue changes but even that still relates to the original choice. Finally, the ending pulls a Mass Effect 3 by making all your previous choices irrelevant. It all boils down to a number of options which change when entered, all ending in 'goodbye'. It's fustrating seeing these characters just give up and stop talking. In conclusion, it's a great consept, I love the style and story yet the previously mentioned points work against it. In a word: Disapointing.

reviewText:
I find it sort of funny reading the other reviews for this game, because I went in without any prior knowledge of what I was getting into, and while a lot of people who played this seem to be thinking about missed chances with a girl they were into, I'm mostly just almost uncomfortably reminded of the passive aggressive BS friendships of my youth.

There's probably some interesting things to be said in regards to gender dynamics since I'm playing as a lesbian woman and a lot of the reviews are probably from straight/bi men, but I'm not going to get into that.

It was well written in that it was all very true to the early 2000's special brand of nostalgia, but in that sense its also sort of a straight up banality simulator. These are the kinds of lukewarm social shenanigans I try to avoid in real life and yet I find myself reinacting them in a video game. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

It still gets a recommend because there's nothing wrong with the game itself. It's just that the subject matter is something I personally find just reminds me of all the time I rolled my eyes at my buddies's stupid relationship drama and awkward social ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• footing. Emily was actually the furthest thing away from being attractive so when I said Goodbye" at the end it was because I was officially done with her crap."

reviewText: probably not for people who play actual visual novels. whenever you pick an option you have to type it out but thats too much work so just bash the keys and get it over with. i couldnt find any option to skip this, making it extremely tiring if you want to play through the game again. theres really only 2 endings where emily either stops talking to you or you get bored of talking to eachother, besides, if there were other endings that would be fun to get you'd still have to sit through the god damn typing. the other aspect of the game is that you have to play along, which is a pet peeve of mine in any fiction. you have to make up what happened outside of talking to emily yourself and you will probably end up just for fun disliking characters that have little to no elaboration on them. game never asks for your gender, so if you're a woman enjoy your possibly temporary homosexuality. theres no response to outright reject any advances emily tries to make for you (probably out of fear of homophobia or some stupid ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•) you never get the option of saying you're not a lesbian/interested in her. i always felt different ways when emily would say something than the dialogue would give. for the heck of it i let her come over and visit me at college for the weekend then it starts acting like shes accusing me of having taken advantage of her in a vulnerable time. i really wanted to tell her to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off, and the game is never clear over what actually happened over that period of time because you're only given the portion of the story for when you're talking directly to emily. that makes things super confusing because it's incredibly hard to deliver a reaction to something if you dont even know the details of what happened. overall pretty awful in terms of story (which is pretty much what the entire game is tbh). save yourself the time and play something else.

reviewText: While this instant messaging/relationship sim has some interesting mechanics, such as requiring you tap something out on the keyboard as you type" the messages you've selected
date: as well as an appealingly nostalgic Windows XP/AIM vibe
recommended: the game suffers from having an intensely irritating central character.\n\nThis short conversation-selection-based text adventure revolves around your chat sessions with Emily over the course of a few years as the two of you leave school and go to university. Unfortunately

reviewText: So I managed to  make it to 2007 and at the time i was dating emma, she was all I could ask for a slim-thick woman, light-skinned. All I'm sayin is she had the whole package. I graduated from business school, with a small loan of a million dollars, got engaged with emma.  things went smooth till I went to an affair site where i met someone for a one-night stand..anyways, it was a good night. Next day I'm at my boy Mike's house at his cinco de mayo barbeque, I tell him about the one night stand and how i felt all this regret about it and he totally supported me on it. several days later emma starts acting differently but I didnt take it to any consideration. One night in bed listening to Drake, I was reminicing about the times I had with Emily on AIM. so i contacted Nev from the show catfish to find out where I could find Emily, we recoreded a whole show for MTV, i got paid very well by the way. He helped me get her personal information including her skype so I send her a message about, how I was wrong about not feeling the same way and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. she responds right-away, says she's going through a divorce with Brad and he owes her over 20 thousand dollars in child support. I told her, sorry to hear that and we spoke from there and we grew a small friendship back. She paid for my ticket to California where she stays. And I told Emma that I was going on a business trip, was going to meet my future mentor Martin Shkreli. I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you not, she believed it. So I landed in LA, where Emily picked me up in her Honda Civic. I was second guessing whether to get in the car but she was wearing some tight pants bruh...anways we get to her house, this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• lives in the middle of the projects. She introduces me to Brad which is now a leader of some drug-traffiking gang up in LA, and she introduces me to 3 little mexican boys who claim to be her sons. Like...brad was white how did they come out like that? I RAN MY ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• TO A HOTEL.  I took my time to catch a flight back before I make any mistakes and ruin my life with Emily's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ass. On the flight back I was just regretting leaving Emma for that side piece, so i wrote her a letter telling her how much I loved her and bought her a bottle of port wine at the airport, them ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s cost like 200 hunnit dollars. I get home to catch Mike in my bed all up on my fiance Emma...\n\n10/10

reviewText:
Right, let me get things straight.
This is a game about trying to get a girl.
Game almost forces you to say that you got together with another girl in the midst of trying to get this one,
Dafuq.
Anyway,
for a free to play game this is really well done. The gameplay was responsive and I don't even know if it's possible to encounter bugs in a game like this. (P.S. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing love the sounds).
Although, the game is minimalistic and the gameplay isn't 169% next-gen immersive, the game still manages to do its job exceptionally well.
The feels factor of this game that the creator tried to do with game worked kind of well and I can definately see something like this happeneing in the real world, and it is amazing how the game flowed throughout itself and how the plot was seamless.

Feels = 6/10. Not worth crying over but it definately hits hard, especially of you can connect and relate to the situation you are put in.

Gameplay = 9/10. Smooth, responsive, I don't have to wait 10 years to get into the next chapter, although I felt that the responses to about 33% of the texts sent could have a little more variety, definately a good game for what it is.

Plot = 10/10. The plot of the story was seamless and due to the fact that anyone can easily relate to this and events similar to this are easily imaginable or probably have happened before in a fashion somewhat resembling this. Once again, This can really hit home for some people.

Price = 10/10. Although this is a free to play indie game, I would've easily payed money for a game like this.

Overall = 7.5/10. This is a really good game to just pick up and play if you're just really bored one night or you just have 30 minutes to kill. Even if you're in none of those situations, I would definately recommend picking up this game and trying it out for a bit. And it's not like it is a huge game that's going to take 3 hours to download and install, it's only about 100MB and easily the best 100MB .exe file that I have executed in quite a while.

Huge kudos to the creator for making such a great game! And also once again, this is a tiny pick up and play indie game, and for what it is, it definately passes with flying colors!

-Chunder
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Emily is Away ReviewNostalgic indie game based on trust and friendship.\n\nEh, it was alright. It really isn't as emotional as people make it out to be. It's extremely short which is alright seeing as it's free. I didn't really think that I played much of a role in the game. Some of the choices you get to make get completely reversed and you don't even get to say what you want to say. It was okay for an indie game, just extremely overrated and nothing compared to Her Story. I really did have high hopes for this game and was extremely excited for it. Definitely give it a go but don't expect the game to impact you as much as others say it will.

reviewText: This game makes you press buttons on your keyboard to simulate typing. That's right.\nIt's supposed to immerse you in the story. But after the first chapter I found myself sitting idly, mashing buttons with one hand while my character typed and erases his messages, which were halfhearted at best.\nI should also bring up that the choices the character makes that matter aren't yours. He can go to a party, and Emily will be there and mention it later. Then she questions choices you" made there
hoursPlayed: the game just brings you back to the chat window.\nThe ending I got seemed to be a comment about how sometimes you just can't be close to someone the way you used to
voteText: which is a fine message. Sometimes you can't do anything about it and just drift apart. But it felt like the character didn't try
helpfulPercent: or we weren't given the right choices.\nIf there's one thing I took from this game
votesHelpful: it's to not let my actual relationships end up like this again. Still
votesTotal: for a game
votesFunny: it's not as involved as I feel it should be
commentsCount: so I don't recommend it."

reviewText:
6.1/10 - A successful serving of nostalgia!

This game just makes you smile a little. You are a high school senior chatting on AIM. For the thousands who did this same thing.. thumbs up already.

This game is clever. You enter your information and chat with a girl from school. Each year the dynamic changes as you realize you love her. The amount of times you have to push a button is really rediculous but aside from that this game is a winner.

Much higher marks if you could communicate with more ease.

It's FREE. Play it.

reviewText:
Ok AIM simulator, bland though.

Biggest dissapointment is the single ending no matter what choices you make.  The games is a missed opportunity, narrativly.

I also felt the game's portrayal of the titular emily was, honestly, sexist and stereotypical.

Well made enough to fool me though, so I played through three times trying for a different outcome. The mechanics, UI, and easter eggs were thoughtful and well implemented.

I'm still going with not reccommended, because there are way better games in the same style that have better story and characters.  Check out this person's next project, because they are on the right track, but skip this one.

reviewText: I've only played one run-through so I'm no sure if there's very different outcomes to the one that happened for me. However this game is a suprisingly deep narritive about the relationship between two people over the course of several years against the backdrop of early noughties IM technology. Emily Is Away is a story about the confusion of love and provides a haunting image how friendship between two individuals can fade over time despite having been best friends, something I imagine most people can relate to (I certainly can). I feel thoroughly depressed now.

reviewText:
This game made me relive one of the worst periods of my entire life. But it also made me relive one of the best periods of my life.
It feels like this game was modeled after my adventures of falling in love.

The friendzone ain't a myth. It's not the thing where neckbeards think that women owe them their love, but it's this bizarre phase right after you confess your feelings, but the other person keeps talking to you, but this time avoiding anything that brings up that" subject
date: dodging anything that might even hint at LOVE and DATING. It results in your friendship dying off completely
recommended: to the point of either you being too scared to even say anything
hoursPlayed:
or the other person just cutting you away from your life. To the point of making you wish you had never confessed your feelings.

reviewText:
This was the worst emotional rollercoaster I have ever been on. I imagined myself back in high school, having that one crush that I always thought I could have gotten if I played my cards right.

The sound effects, buddy profiles with lyrics from mid-2000's classics really brought me back into the AIM era.

I feel like there might be more endings to the game depending on which options you select, but I'm currently so soul-crushed by the ending I received that I cannot bring myself to do it.

reviewText:
Controllable Helplessness: Friendzone Edition

It's a free game that's worth a try if you have nothing else to do. Do take note that the hitboxes are terrible though, so you'll end up spending a bit of time trying to find where exactly the game wants you to click. Also, the layer of choice is, sadly, an illusion Don't bother trying multiple runs to get new endings and outcomes -- there are none. You lost the game when you started it.

Check it out. Regardless of what you end up thinking about it, there's little-to-no loss on your behalf. In the end you'll most likely either end up liking it or being indifferent towards it.

reviewText:
This is one of those 'diamond in the rough' Free to Play games  that you don't expect to be good until you experience it for yourself.

The old computer and AOL messenging sounds do a good job in creating a fittingly nostalgic yet lonely atmosphere.  The dialogue is also impressively realistic which I really appreciate as it's challenging to find somewhat similar games (simulation, VN, etc) where character dialogue isn't over the top or just plain ridiculous.  The conversations in Emily is Away are simple and not too long- exactly the length a conversation needs to be.  Each subsequent conversation slowly and effectively leads your emotions into a constricted knot of fondness, frustration, and regret.

Definitely try this game if you're willing to relive the dismal memories of an old crush or if you generally just want to feel like an empty shell once you're done.

reviewText:
not only is this simplistically fantastic, it's also a great throwback to the days of instant messaging. it's short and sweet but it still wound up blowing me away. and what i love most about it is the great structure to it and how you have to actually type out the messages rather than simply choosing your dialogue option, which gives it an in-depth and realistic feel to it, as if you're actually back in the early 2000s messaging your friend emily on AOL

overall, it's a really great game for something so simple and i'm looking forward to playing through it again and again through all of the dialogue options 15/10

also you get your heart ripped out in five chapters so that's nice too i guess

reviewText: A truly touching and depressing story that will take you on a roller coaster ride all the way through. You start as a High School senior in the 00s, who uses AIM for kicks to talk with his friends, I don't know how they got away with using the AIM graphics. It is the end of your highschool life. You and your friends would like to celebrate, as any average youthful adults would. You and Emily discuss going to the party, but there is this prickly sore in your side named Brad, Brad has been flirting with Emily on the internet.  Watch as you make the worst ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing descisions possible, watch as you ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out with certain dialogue choices. Will you end up with Emily? Will Brad sexually coerce her? Will it all end in flames? Will you kiss her? Will you choose to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• her? I won't give anything away, but the fact there is a very emotionally touching yet simple ending and we all learn that we have known girls in our youth like Emily. Overall, I say try it, It is really deep and well done for a free to plane online dating sim type game. I'd reccomend you play it just for the plot and emotional experience of it all. As a FTP 9/10, as an actual game, 7.4/10

reviewText: I was skeptical of this game at first (having played a few indie text based games before) however I was blown away by the result. This game simulated truthfully what these types of situations are like and places you in a scenario that we could all easily fall into ourselves. Whilst this game depressed me to no end as it reminded of a similar situation I have been through I think it is a short masterpiece in an indie game package.\n10/10 would cry over a fictional girl again.
